title: 104_hr3048
content: The Act may be cited as the "Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996". Judicial review is addressed in the Act. Section 611 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow small entities to petition for judicial review of final rules that were certified to have no significant economic impact or had a regulatory flexibility analysis prepared. A court with jurisdiction to review rules for compliance can also review the certification or analysis. The amended Section 611 of title 5, United States Code allows small entities to petition for judicial review of final rules certified to have no significant economic impact or with a regulatory flexibility analysis. Courts with jurisdiction to review rules for compliance can also review the certification or analysis. The term 'affected small entity' refers to a small entity adversely affected by the final rule. The analysis is made public. The term 'affected small entity' refers to a small entity adversely affected by the final rule. Courts can review certification or analysis of rules for compliance. The court can review the certification or analysis of rules for compliance with regulatory flexibility requirements. If the court finds the certification or analysis to be arbitrary, capricious, or not in accordance with the law, corrective action may be ordered. If the agency fails to comply within a specified period, further action may be taken. The court can review the certification or analysis of rules for compliance with regulatory flexibility requirements. If the agency fails to prepare the required analysis or take corrective action within a specified period, the court may stay the rule or grant appropriate relief. The court must consider the rule of prejudicial error when making any determination or granting relief. In a judicial review of a rule, any regulatory flexibility analysis shall be part of the record. The court must consider the rule of prejudicial error in reviewing rules. Any regulatory flexibility analysis for a rule will be part of the record for judicial review. This amendment applies to final agency rules issued after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. RULES COMMENTED ON BY SBA CHIEF COUNSEL FOR ADVOCACY. Section 612 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to require agencies to transmit proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publication. Section 612 of title 5, United States Code, now mandates agencies to send proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publication. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy can provide a written statement on the impact of the proposed rule on small entities within 15 days of receiving the documents. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy can provide a written statement on the impact of proposed rules on small entities, which must be published in the Federal Register along with the agency's response. Special rules apply to proposed rules issued by certain federal agencies. Special rules apply to proposed rules issued by certain federal agencies to ensure the safety and soundness of federally insured depository institutions, credit unions, and government-sponsored housing enterprises. These rules are not subject to certain requirements. Congress believes that the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration should have the ability to appear as amicus curiae in court cases reviewing rules.
